header.title: The Scroll of Set - November 1995
header.category: Western Esotericism, Occultism, Left-Hand Path, Setian Philosophy

central_thesis: The core philosophical and practical framework of the Temple of Set centers on the individual's self-transformation (Xeper) through the conscious application of will, confronting the unknown, mastering both subjective and objective realities, and embracing antinomianism to manifest a unique, deified existence, facilitated by a structured initiatory system.

structure_content.summary: This article discusses the Setian journey of self-transformation, termed 'Becoming' or 'Xeper', highlighting the initial daunting steps of ordering the self and eradicating detrimental routines. It emphasizes the importance of perseverance and willpower to overcome lapses from one's goals, noting that facing personal weaknesses in ritual is a significant challenge in the Left-Hand Path.

structure_content.chapter_title: [2] The Future, an Aspect of the Gift of Set
structure_content.summary: This piece explores the Setian view of time and the future, distinguishing 'will' (power over the future) from 'desire'. It asserts that the 'Gift of Set' enables Setians to actively 'will the future' rather than passively letting things 'happen'. The unknown future is linked to the 'blackest part of the Black Flame', requiring Setians to overcome fear and assert will to 'create time' and manifest their future in the present, aligning with Xeper's definition as 'coming into being under will'.

structure_content.chapter_title: [3] Horus & Set - The Year of the Heb-Sed
structure_content.summary: This article analyzes the symbolic unification of Set and Horus, drawing parallels to the Egyptian Heb-Sed rite. It proposes that 'HarWer' represents a cosmic order where Horus the Elder governs the subjective universe (thoughts, feelings) and Set is the core self. For full self-consciousness, Set needs Horus the Elder. It advocates for harmony within the subjective universe for Setian initiation, while antinomianism is reserved for the objective universe and Right-Hand Path society, contrasting this with Horus the Younger who symbolizes the objective world Setians should dominate.

A brief mythological study of the serpent motif, including the Australian Rainbow Serpent (a creation spirit of energy and change) and the Egyptian Apep Serpent (an adversary to Ra, or an aspect of Set). It re-tells a myth of Horus trapping Apep and relates serpent powers to subconscious forces, powers above/below ground, and primitive creation theories.
An administrative announcement for 'The Sentinels' Trident', a semi-annual publication, soliciting articles on topics like pylon meetings and newsletter content for upcoming issues.
A short poem, seemingly a critique of a 'Lord' who is always victorious and gathers 'Faith from Fable', implying a skepticism towards established religious power.

An announcement detailing the dedication of the first Canadian Pylon, Tuatha De Danann, including its founding members, geographic area (southern Ontario, upstate New York), and diverse magical interests such as Celtic/Runic magic, Vampyrism, Setian poetry, dreams, and Lovecraft studies.
An announcement for the Xronos BBS, a Left-Hand Path bulletin board system operated by the Xronos Pylon, offering private and public forums and seeking text file uploads from interested users.

A list of individuals recognized for advancement to various degrees within the Temple of Set, including Priest of Set III° and Adept II°, along with their dates of recognition and the names of their recognizers.

Reviews two films: 'Seven', described as a dark, psychotic thriller showcasing 'insanity fueled by Christianity', and 'Show Girls', an erotic and controversial film depicting the 'price of fame' and the noble/bestial natures of human relationships in the glamour industry.

This article provides a detailed analysis of the Temple of Set's degree system as a 'formula for the evolution of consciousness', emphasizing Xeper as the sole tool for self-realization, not measured by degrees. It outlines the characteristics and challenges of each degree (First through Sixth), from 'escape from prison' and self-shaping at the Initiate level, to mastery of life and 'war' at the Master level, and finally affecting others to 'grow into gods' at the Ipsissimi stage. It highlights the importance of overcoming fear and achieving harmony within one's subjective universe throughout the process.

An announcement for the formation of the Pan Pylon and its 'Io Pan Working', a non-traditional Greater Black Magic ritual using non-verbal methods, discordant recorder music to focus will, widdershins pacing, and ancient texts to connect with Pan and primordial Arcadia. The Pylon aims to advance Xeper through these unique methods.

A poetic and evocative piece describing a magical journey of sensing power, witnessing ancient magic and the building of monuments, and experiencing the Black Flame as the core of creation. It speaks of the Setian will molding reality, merging 'Two Lands', unleashing inner power, and being 'Reborn by the Gift of the Black Flame in wisdom, power, and essence'.

This article explores the historical and philosophical link between Satanism and Setianism, particularly Dr. Aquino's founding of the Temple of Set as a manifestation of Set. It frames Setians, especially II°+ Initiates, as 'antichrists' from a magical perspective, linking 'energized consciousness' to the 'Mark of the Beast'. It challenges Setians to confront Biblical prophecies and their own predispositions, advocating for a strategic shift away from public Satanism for the Temple's preservation while maintaining antinomian principles against Christianity.

A reflection on Temple of Set Conclaves as 'large workings' that integrate individual rites, thought, and divine inspiration into objective reality. It details how Setians' wills and actions shape these events, creating a 'magic' that transforms experience and provides material for ongoing self-transformation, with the goal of making everyday life similarly magical.

This article discusses the 'Graal' (lapsit exillis) in a Setian context, defining it as a 'milestone' or 'Remanifestation'—a significant event on the slow, step-by-step path of Xeper towards Runa. It emphasizes that initiation is a gradual process, making these milestones precious indicators of progress and highlighting the unique nature of the 'stone of purest kind' in Setian philosophy.

key_concepts.definition: "Coming into being under will"; the continuous process of self-transformation and the evolution of consciousness, a core Setian principle.

The unique essence or consciousness inherent within each Setian. Its 'blackest part' is identified as the fear of the unknown future, which must be confronted and overcome through the assertion of will.
The distinct Setian ability to think about the future, to plan for it, and to exert conscious power (will) over it, differing from mere desire or passive acceptance.
Power over the future; the conscious ability to cause change and to manifest the future as desired, as opposed to simply wanting or wishing.
The magical path of individual self-transformation and deification, which involves the deliberate destruction of old self-aspects and the manifestation of new, beneficial ones.
An ancient Egyptian jubilee rite, symbolically interpreted within Setianism as the unification of Set and Horus, representing the integration of different aspects of reality and consciousness.

A concept representing the cosmic order, comprising Set and Horus. Specifically, Horus the Elder is seen as ordering the subjective universe, while Set represents the core self, requiring this inner harmony for dynamic activity.

The principle of actively opposing or transcending external laws, particularly those of the objective universe and Right-Hand Path society. It is applied externally, not to the internal, subjective universe.
A structured initiatory path within the Temple of Set designed for the evolution of consciousness, providing a framework for progressive mastery and transformation from Initiate to Ipsissimi.
The 'sense of the hidden' that attracts aspirants to the Temple, representing an intrinsic pull towards deeper esoteric truths.
Symbolically interpreted as 'lapsit exillis' or an 'insignificant/meagre stone', representing the milestones or 'Remanifestations' that mark progress along the gradual, step-by-step path of Xeper.
A significant event or milestone in a Setian's life that acts as a stimulus for their continued progress and self-transformation on the path of Xeper.
The magic of spells and sorcery. Within the Maga/Magus degree, it is considered secondary to the 'art of causing change' through the utterance of the Word, serving as a supporting tool.

practical_system.description: The Setian practical system centers on the individual's ongoing 'Xeper' or self-transformation, driven by conscious will and the 'Gift of Set'. It involves a continuous process of ordering the self, eradicating detrimental aspects, and manifesting new beneficial ones. The system emphasizes actively willing the future, rather than passively accepting it. This includes mastering one's subjective universe (Horus the Elder) while applying antinomian principles to the objective world (Horus the Younger). Progression through a structured degree system (Initiate to Ipsissimi) provides a framework for evolving consciousness, with each stage requiring specific tasks like self-discovery, communication, and strategic action. Communal workings like Conclaves and Pylons serve as 'large workings' that amplify individual will and facilitate collective magical endeavors.
tools: Discordant recorder music (for Io Pan Working)
Homeric Hymn to Pan (for Io Pan Working)
rituals: Self-transformation practices (ordering the self, eradicating detrimental aspects, manifesting beneficial ones)
Ritual chamber work to face personal weaknesses
Exercises to identify and reframe passive future expressions into active willed actions ('What will I do?')
Stoking the Black Flame to project will into the future
Visualizations to explore the void of the future
'Io Pan Working' (a Greater Black Magic ritual involving non-verbal methods, discordant music, widdershins pacing, and reading Homeric Hymn to Pan to focus collective will)
Conclave workings (collective magical endeavors amplifying individual rites)

relevant_quotes.text: The oldest and strongest emotion of mankind is fear, and the oldest and strongest fear is the fear of the unknown.

Xeper is defined as “coming into being under will". There is an interesting shift in the time-continuum inherent in this definition: “will” being the future, "coming” being the present. Looking at it this way, we could interpret this definition as “making your future manifest in the present".
The Great Work, and learning to slay that many-headed hydra, fear, is perhaps initiation's greatest lesson.

The only way that we can preserve the Temple of Set seems to be to move away from the public appearance of Satanism. One does not, as someone pointed out to me, have to be a "Satanist" to be AntiChristian. By our very nature we are against Christianity, like it or not. Not as in The Omen, but from a magical standpoint, every II°+ Initiate of the Temple of Set is an “antichrist”.

critical_analysis.relevance: This document is highly relevant to understanding the core philosophies and practices of the Temple of Set in the mid-1990s. It details the unique Setian interpretation of willpower, time, self-transformation (Xeper), the initiatory degree system, and their relationship with Egyptian mythology (Horus & Set). It also addresses internal and external challenges, such as the public perception of Satanism and the practicalities of communal workings (conclaves, pylons). The recurring emphasis on overcoming fear, asserting will, and the continuous process of 'Becoming' provides a strong, coherent magical system.
critical_analysis.target_audience: Initiates and Adepts of the Temple of Set, practitioners of the Left-Hand Path, academics studying modern Western Esotericism and occult organizations, and individuals interested in the philosophy and magical systems of Setianism. The technical language and internal references suggest a primary audience already familiar with Setian concepts and internal discourse.
